thread.title: The eight most-anticipated new theme park attractions in 2016
thread.title_full: The eight most-anticipated new theme park attractions in 2016

title: The eight most-anticipated new theme park attractions in 2016
text:
241 CONNECT 213 TWEET 80 LINKEDIN 3 COMMENT EMAIL MORE There will be all kinds of rides and attractions, big and small, opening in 2016, but none are more anticipated than Harry Potter and the Forbidden Journey at Universal Studios Hollywood. Universal Studios Hollywood, Universal Studios Hollywood Fullscreen Forbidden Journey will be part of The Wizarding World of Harry Potter, which will invite visitors to explore the village of Hogsmeade and also include highly themed shows, dining, and shops. Universal Studios Hollywood, Universal Studios Hollywood Fullscreen Other rides from the Florida park, including Flight of the Hippogriff, will also appear in the Hollywood version. Universal Studios Hollywood, Universal Studios Hollywood Fullscreen Skull Island: Reign of Kong will be returning King Kong to his rightful place at Universal Studios Orlando, in the Islands of Adventure park. Universal Studios Orlando Fullscreen Expect a wild ride with the likelihood of some enormous animatronic creatures and Universal's trademark in-your-face action. Universal Studios Orlando Fullscreen Six Flags' DC Comics-themed ride, Battle for Metropolis, will feature sophisticated roving motion base vehicles, 3D imagery, stunning animatronics, interactive laser guns, and other theme park trickery. Six Flags Entertainment Fullscreen Citizen recruits will be helping Superman, Batman, and their Justice League buddies defeat The Joker and Lex Luthor in their scheme to take down the Man of Steel's adopted city. Six Flags Entertainment Fullscreen Known more for soaring coasters and over-the-edge thrills, Six Flags demonstrated that it could deliver stunning, story-based, E-Ticket attractions when it debuted similar Battle for Metropolis rides in 2015 at its parks in St. Louis and Texas. Six Flags Entertainment Fullscreen Epcot's Maelstrom attraction at the Norway pavilion is getting an Olafian makeover and will reopen as Frozen Ever After next year. A new Frozen musical will also debut at Disney's California Adventure. Disney Fullscreen Legoland brings their popular line of Ninjago toys to their park with Lego Ninjago - The Ride. Legoland Fullscreen Passengers aboard the unique new 4D ride will use their hands – and only their hands – to direct lightning blasts, ice crystals, and other virtual weapons at targets and rack up points. Legoland Fullscreen Visitors will be able to enter the science fiction realm of the popular Mass Effect video game series next season at California's Great America. Bioware Fullscreen The now-closed Luigi's Flying Tires at Disney's California Adventure will be replaced by Luigi's Rollickin' Roadsters, a trackless ride system that features anthropomorphic dancing cars at Casa della Tires. Disney The 2015 season has barely wound down, but theme parks are already hyping what's on the way for 2016. We've highlighted the top coasters that will be rolling out next year. Now, let's take a look at everything else that's coming to parks soon from a king-sized hairy ape to a mega-popular Harry wizard.
Harry Potter and the Forbidden Journey at Universal Studios Hollywood, Hollywood, Calif.
There will be all kinds of rides and attractions, big and small, opening in 2016, but none is more anticipated than Forbidden Journey. It will use a robotic arm vehicle, projected media, and practical sets to whisk muggles away on an adventure with Harry and his wizard pals. The queue leading to the ride will be an adventure in itself. Guests will enter Hogwarts Castle (which is typically forbidden for muggles) and encounter oil paintings that spring to life, an indoor snowstorm, and other magical moments.
The ride will be similar to the existing Forbidden Journey attraction at Florida's Universal Orlando with one major difference: The media for the Hollywood version will be projected in high resolution 3D and should be sharper, brighter, and make for a more immersive experience. Forbidden Journey will be part of The Wizarding World of Harry Potter, which will invite visitors to explore the village of Hogsmeade and also include highly themed shows, dining, and shops.
Skull Island: Reign of Kong at Islands of Adventure, part of Universal Orlando, Orlando, Fla.
At the park where Pottermania first began, an old friend will be returning. Universal's poster ape used to terrorize guests at sister park, Universal Studios Florida, until he was banished to make room for the Revenge of the Mummy indoor coaster ride. Kong's new home will be in Islands of Adventure's Jurassic Park area. If the attraction will be similar to Universal Studio Hollywood's King Kong 360 3-D (and I suspect it will), the big guy will be focused more on battling dinosaurs than defenseless park patrons. Expect a wild ride with the likelihood of some enormous animatronic creatures and Universal's trademark in-your-face action.
Justice League: Battle for Metropolis at Six Flags Great America, Gurnee, Ill.
Speaking of in-your-face attractions, Six Flags will be borrowing from Universal's playbook for its DC Comics-themed ride, Battle for Metropolis, which will feature sophisticated roving motion base vehicles, 3D imagery, stunning animatronics, interactive laser guns, and other theme park trickery. Citizen recruits will be helping Superman, Batman, and their Justice League buddies defeat The Joker and Lex Luthor in their scheme to take down the Man of Steel's adopted city. Known more for soaring coasters and over-the-edge thrills, Six Flags demonstrated that it could deliver stunning, story-based, E-Ticket attractions when it debuted similar Battle for Metropolis rides in 2015 at its parks in St. Louis and Texas.
Frozen Ever After at Epcot, Lake Buena Vista, Fla.
Disney's Frozen juggernaut continues. In 2016, it will even invade Disney World's somewhat staid, edutainment park, Epcot. The Maelstrom attraction at the Norway pavilion is getting an Olafian makeover and will reopen as Frozen Ever After. Guests will travel by boat to Arendelle, the North Mountain, Queen Elsa's Ice Palace, and other locales from the hugely popular animated film. There will undoubtedly be a stirring chorus of "Let It Go."
Frozen Stage Musical at Disney California Adventure, Anaheim, Calif.
Speaking of the Frozen juggernaut, Anna, Elsa, and their Scandinavian posse will be taking over the stage from Aladdin at Disney California Adventure's Hyperion Theater. The new show will have some big, curly-toed genie shoes to fill. The Aladdin musical has been both a popular and critical success. Disney is promising some nifty effects in its retelling of the Frozen saga. And yes, there will undoubtedly be a stirring chorus of "Let It Go."
Lego Ninjago - The Ride at Legoland California, Carlsbad, Calif.
The ninja heroes featured in the Ninjago TV show and Lego building sets use their hands to engage in martial arts. Likewise, passengers aboard the unique new 4D ride will use their hands – and only their hands – to direct lightning blasts, ice crystals, and other virtual weapons at targets and rack up points.
Mass Effect at California's Great America, Santa Clara, Calif.
Visitors will be able to enter the science fiction realm of the popular Mass Effect videogame series next season at California's Great America. The park is retrofitting its existing Action Theater and will present a 4D adventure that will incorporate motion simulator seats, 3D media, and sensory effects. A live actor will lead guests on the intergalactic journey.
Luigi's Rollickin' Roadsters at Disney California Adventure, Anaheim, Calif.
Cars Land, the highly immersive area at Disney California Adventure based on Pixar's Cars movies, has been wildly successful – except for Luigi's Flying Tires. The air hockey-like ride never quite worked as intended and closed earlier this year. Its replacement will invite guests to pile into anthropomorphic dancing cars at Casa della Tires. The vehicles will reportedly use a trackless ride system and be able to interact and perform sophisticated choreography with one another. It will be the first Disney park attraction in the USA to feature trackless ride technology (although SeaWorld Orlando beat Disney to the punch with its trackless Antarctica: Empire of the Penguin ride).
